Topic.Title: Local Corp is Master of Relevance in Mobile Shopping - And that’s the key: it has to be a relevant deal

Message.Msg: Last guidance is guidance for a quarter-billion-company, but the market-cap of yesterday was only 43 million Last Fiscal 2013 Financial Guidance of Local Corp: The company is increasing its financial guidance for full year 2013. Revenue - The company now expects 2013 revenue of between $95 million and $97 million. Adjusted EBITDA – Positive Adjusted EBITDA for 2013 is expected to be approximately $5.4 million. Less A correction doesn't exist more than one month after the end of Q3 - and therefore the numbers will be next Thursday in the expectations. 51.8 million revenues in the second half of 2013 as the result of the guidance of 95-97 million in 2013 and the reported numbers of Q1 + Q2 Q1/2013: 21.5 million (reported) Q2/2013: 22.7 million (reported) Q3/2013: 24.6 million (result of the guidance of Local Corp for the complete year and my quarterly estimate) Q4/2013: 27.2 million (result of the guidance of Local Corp for the complete year and my quarterly estimate) On the base of 24.6 million revenues in Q3 we have only 0.45-times-revenues.

Topic.Title: AMZN's Q3 revenue beat

Message.Msg: No Prime structure is similar to Costco and other membership fee structures. "Fees already booked as revenue and profit in Q3 blah, blah..." The fees don't all get booked at once during the quarter. They are spread out over the entire term of the annual contract: "Amounts received in advance for services, including amounts received for Amazon Prime and web services, are deferred and recognized as revenue over the term." (Amazon Annual Report 2012). Please learn to check your facts before posting.

Topic.Title: AMZN's Q3 revenue beat

Message.Msg: You are a mental nano-midget. Does Costco embed THE EQUIVALENT OF free movies in its membership? YES. The net effect of offering some things free and a lot more and especially of the higher demand movies as paid has the same NET EFFECT as Costoc offering a deep discount on all of its DVDs. Does it embed THE EQUIVALENT OF free 2 day shipping? Yes. Costoc offering a deep discount on all of its merchandise has the same NET EFFECT as Amazon offering special shipping benefits to Prime members. For online retail, the cost of the product to the consumer is the entire amount he pays in the transaction INCLUDING SHIPPING shipping. ANYTHING REDUCING THAT FIGURE IS THE SAME THING AS APPLYING A DISCOUNt to that TRANSACTION AMOUNT. It does not matter whether you call this discount shipping or some limited viewing of selected movies.. Your inablity to comprehend this simple concept goes a long way in explaining why you could blunder so badly as to now have a $120 per share on your Amazon short.

Topic.Title: AMZN's Q3 revenue beat

Message.Msg: No, you are wrong. I just quote the annual report to you. "Amounts received in advance for services, including amounts received for Amazon Prime and web services, are deferred and recognized as revenue over the term." Customers pay the amount at one time (upfront) but all of that revenue is not recorded on the income statement in the quarter that is received. Most of each fee will be booked temporarily on the balance sheet as "deferred revenue". So only about $20 in 3Q for each new customer was recognized. Are you a native speaker of English with an IQ higher than short wreckstrategy's? Do you understand what "deferred" means?

Topic.Title: AMZN's Q3 revenue beat

Message.Msg: Amazon has razor thin actual margin and then they have to pay more in 2-day ship than they get from the prime fees. It gets masked with growth in prime fees next quarter, but when the prime enrollment stops growing, then you are left with a sudden big drop in profit starting on the quarter where the music stops playing, but continued bigger losses 3 more quarters since it was a year obligation and growth has stopped bringing in the extra money to cover it.

Topic.Title: Amazon Free Cash Flow

Message.Msg: An economic bubble: A bubble is similar to a Ponzi scheme in that one participant gets paid by contributions from a subsequent participant (until inevitable collapse). A bubble involves ever-rising prices in an open market (for example stock, housing, or tulip bulbs) where prices rise because buyers bid more because prices are rising. Bubbles are often said to be based on the "greater fool" theory. As with the Ponzi scheme, the price exceeds the intrinsic value of the item, but unlike the Ponzi scheme, there is no single person misrepresenting the intrinsic value.

Topic.Title: The more you boneheadz argue and bet short amzn's sheiotty fundiez - the higher it will go, stupidz

Message.Msg: Short selling does not drive a stock price up. In total its a zero sum game. You sell short, then ultimately buy back the same number of shares. A net increase in shorting over time will drive down a stock's price, everything else equal. Of course, the opposite is true when the net short position declines over a period of time. And it is true that a large percent of shares short is a catalyst to future stock price increases (since those shares must ultimately be bought back). But of course, those same shares pushed the price down when they were shorted. So zero sum game. I see all the time people saying an increase in shorting is driving a stock UP. Not true.

Topic.Title: The more you boneheadz argue and bet short amzn's sheiotty fundiez - the higher it will go, stupidz

Message.Msg: Oil is about as high as it has ever been, seasonally adjusted. Those technologies help mitigate the underlying physics of depletion based energy production, but the physics still applies. Further, the unit economics have changed and depletion rates are very high in tight oil/shale, which alters the nature of the intermediate term supply curve. I'm very willing to consider alternatives and test/reject my hypothesis. Buy, I do so based upon FACTS, not high level assertions that don't stand up to the facts. Keep having at me. But try doing so with actual facts (MMBOE production increase compared to net imorts, deplation rates, required investment to exploit these technologies globally, etc). Energy will play a very critical role in the evolution of global finance. You are misunderstanding how that plays out IMHO...

Topic.Title: The more you boneheadz argue and bet short amzn's sheiotty fundiez - the higher it will go, stupidz

Message.Msg: Sybs, the reason I have at you is that I realize you are intelligent and thoughtful. Dissent and differing POVs are great -- that's how one gets to the right answer faster. I could never have an exchange with the board pumpers like this because they are incapable of critical thought. Seriously, have at me. I'm happy to be proven wrong. FWIW, I think you are conflating multiple energy markets that are not direct substitutes because unlike solar, transporting energy to where it is consumed is a material problem. By now you should know that I analyze things quite carefully, particularly technologies... Try to get a view into how much exploration and drilling costs have increased compared to the increase in production. It isn't all roses on the energy front and the propaganda people are being fed about our unconventional resources....

Message.Title: Mayday! Air is kicking HDX's tail...
Message.Msg: I like to periodically check Amazon's best selling electronics. Chromecast has been #1 basically since launch. HDX has been floundering mid pack, always behind lower cost FireHD platforms. But now, all of the iPad Air accessories are catching and collectively passing HDX (despite AMZN being basically the only material channel for HDX). I guess people aren't so excited about Amazon having direct access to everything after signing the 10 year $600MM CIA contract in light of all the Snowden revelations... Besides, when it gets hacked (and it will), it could become a major tool to swindle people... Amazon overreached with Mayday and it is going to backfire.

Topic.Title: Mayday! Air is kicking HDX's tail...

Message.Msg: The tablet market is satiated. Expect Q4 to disappoint across the board. Macro forces are very negative including Obamacare, sequestration and EBT reductions. The fed's QE is even more ineffective now because the $4T balance sheet is a gorilla. The most healthy thing would be a reset correction now. It's time one way or the other.
